newsitem.title: AFGHANISTAN: Taleban militia capture Kabul, capital quiet.
newsitem.headline: Taleban militia capture Kabul, capital quiet.

text.p: Afghanistan's Taleban Islamic militia entered Kabul in tanks and on foot overnight on Friday, meeting little resistance from government forces which had abandoned the city hours before, witnesses said.
There was no fighting in Kabul.

Celebratory bursts of machine-gun fire and occasional explosions echoed across the city at dawn but the Afghan capital was relatively calm as Taleban fighters set up checkpoints to search vehicles, the witnesses said.
All key government installations appeared to be in Taleban hands including the Presidential Palace and the Ministries of Defence, Security and Foreign Affairs.
No government forces were visible on the city's streets.
Troops had been seen leaving the city some hours before, on the only government-controlled road out of Kabul.

Witnesses said tanks, artillery and trucks loaded with soldiers headed north, apparently towards Jabal us-Sharaj, the headquarters of military chief Ahmad Shah Masood at the entrance to the Panjshir valley.
The fate of President Burhanuddin Rabbani, his military chief Ahmad Shah Masood, and Prime Minister Gulbuddin Hekmatyar was not immediately known.

Deputy foreign minister Adbul Rahim Ghafoorzai told Reuters Television at the United Nations late on Thursday government troops were leaving Kabul to avoid a "bloodbath", and that Rabbani was considering handing over power.
"Masood has decided to retreat to territory north of the city because he didn't want Kabul city to turn into a bloodbath," the minister said.

"The president is in the outskirts to the north and by tomorrow (Friday) will announce his decision whether to leave the capital," he said adding that the president would take the advice of other members of his high council.
He said he thought "there will be a transfer of power, to whom we do not know."
He hoped that Afghanistan's former King, Zahir Shah, ousted in 1973 and now in Rome, would return to the country as even the Taleban would accept him in a leadership role.
Kabul itself was quiet on Friday. Civilians were walking in the streets in the morning past Taleban fighters manning checkpoints and crossroads.
Some people were returning to their homes in the eastern suburbs laden with belongings after fleeing earlier fighting.
Taleban forces entered the city from the west, east and south at about 1.00 a.m. (2130 GMT Thursday).
They stopped in one street in the diplomatic Wazir Akbar Kahan Li neighbourhood and set up a loudspeaker and recited from the Koran for 15 minutes.
The Taleban captured Kabul after a two day offensive in which hundreds of people were killed on both sides, according to the International Committee of the Red Cross.
The Taleban advance began after the Islamic rebels took the town of Sarobi, 70 km (44 miles) east of the capital on Wednesday.

Masood spokesman Amrullah told reporters on Thursday in Kabul that government forces would fight to the death to defend the capital but added: "If Kabul were to fall tomorrow it would not mean resistance would be over".
